caption: This AMD "system on a chip" device (SoC) includes an advanced, 7nm processor along with other types of components. The penny-size processor contains billions of transistors.
An Nvidia TU106 GPU, manufactured in Taiwan using a 12 nm production process. This chip packs billions of transistors into a space the size of a postage stamp.
An older FPGA produced by Xilinx, now a subsidiary of design giant AMD.
Nanoscale transistors observed with an electron microscope. Leading-edge chips, such as the latest AI ASICs, can pack tens of billions of these transistors into a device the size of a fingernail.
An ultra-pure silicon crystal is grown using the floating zone process.
Silicon wafers are inspected in a university lab.
A small-scale EV Group wafer bonder sits in a clean room at the University of California, Davis.
An ion implanter is operated in a research setting.

Close-up of an AMD 7 nm "system on a chip" device. The penny-size processor contains billions of transistors. Producing chips like these requires photolithography equipment produced solely by Dutch and Japanese firms.
EUV lithography equipment in a research setting at the SUNY Polytechnic Institute.
A 28 nm chip sits on the photographer's finger. ArF immersion scanners are among the only photolithography machines capable of producing 28 nm devices.
Patterns in a photomask.
A silicon wafer houses rows of processors. The processors will be cut from the wafer and individually packaged.
An electron-beam (e-beam) lithography device is operated in a research setting. E-beam machinery is often used to produce advanced photomasks.
An e-beam device manufactured by JEOL, a Japanese producer.
The writing head and table of a Heidelberg Instruments laser lithography machine.
Photoresist is spin-coated onto a silicon wafer.
A photomask. Photolithography tools pass light through the mask to transfer its patterns to a silicon wafer, creating minute circuits.
Deposition using the plasma chemical vapor deposition method.
The deposition chamber of a chemical vapor deposition device used in research. The three nozzles spray metal oxides onto the silicon below.
Argon plasma generated in an experimental chamber at the University of Iowa.
A chemical vapor deposition furnace.
Researchers operating an atomic layer deposition reactor at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.
Gold atoms are "sputtered" (deposited) onto a substrate in a physical vapor deposition chamber.
Test structures etched with a deep reactive ion etching tool, magnified 32x using an electron microscope.
Channels etched with a deep reactive ion etching tool. The deepest channel is about 100 micrometers, roughly the width of a human hair.
Side view of an Nvidia processor.
An Nvidia graphics processor manufactured with a 16 nm process. Nanoscale manufacturing is only possible with sophisticated process control equipment.
A research ellipsometer at the University of California, Davis.
Inspecting a silicon sample with an ellipsometer.
Scanning electron microscopes like this Zeiss system are used for dimensions measurement.
Operating an electron microscope in a research setting. Electron microscopes can be used to inspect semiconductor devices for defects.
A transmission electron microscope in use at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory.
An older-generation Intel processor sits in its package. The package protects the processor, removes waste heat, and provides an interface to other devices.
A semiconductor wafer partway through the dicing process.
Part of the package for an Intel Xeon processor.
A researcher applies test probes to a chip.
A wafer probe device.
Details in a graphics processing unit. Specialized software is used to manage the intricate, nanoscale design of modern semiconductors.
Detail from an ARM patent for a circuit device.
Samples of rare earth oxides, a common ingredient in in chemical mechanical planarization slurries.
credit: Peggy Greb/United States Department of Agriculture

caption: An Air Liquide plant in Russia. Air Liquide is a leading supplier of gases for semiconductor manufacturing.
Rail cars for transporting hydrochloric acid, an important chemical for semiconductor production.
Close-up of a pair of empty lead frames. These particular frames have an older design common in consumer electronics.
An older Motorola chip with prominent wiring.
A semiconductor package (with the chip itself removed).
An older AMD processor.
A packaged Nvidia graphics processor, manufactured by Samsung with an 8 nm process. The chip is slightly larger than a U.S. quarter and contains billions of nanoscale transistors.
Close-up of an older Intel Celeron chip in its package.

False-color closeup of an AMD Ryzen processor manufactured with a 12 nm process. Fabricating the billions of nanoscale transistors in this chip required sophisticated equipment produced by only a few suppliers.
At work in a clean room. Microscopic contaminants can compromise the intricate structure of modern semiconductors.
credit: Lynn Freeny/United States Department of Energy

caption: Package (without chip) of an AMD Ryzen processor. Semiconductor packages protect the processor, whisk away heat, and connect the processor to other devices.
Close-up of features on an AMD 4nm chip.
Close-up of features on an AMD 7nm chip manufactured in Taiwan.
Close-up of features on an AMD 5nm chip.
Test structures etched with a deep reactive ion etching tool, magnified 32x using an electron microscope.
Part of the package for an Intel Xeon processor.

Au_sputtering_light.JPG (https://airtable.com/appHpTKGKLOH03Kfa/tblbEVBikkDv1eAbU/recCoqxxEytZFhDYg/fldloNnhS1qgGeExp/attxi3R14gyfr8YAP)
A chemical is spin-coated onto a silicon wafer.
An electron-beam (e-beam) device is operated in a research setting.
